ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: All learning was through a virtual seminar.
1-1 meetings to discuss papers
None

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Skills that I developed within this course was the use of MLA format and how to correctly cite essays. Along with this, I gained a better understanding of how to construct my essays and developed my own style of writing. During class and the readings that we were assigned, I was learning more about virtual reality in an interesting variety of fields, especially during my 3rd Paper where I was able to learn about virtual reality specified towards a specific topic.
I learned how to discuss concepts and better dissect complicated texts. I also learned how to analyze the warrants, arguments, claims, and evidence that an author makes in their writing.
I learned how to analyze texts and write more clearly.
How to write effective arguments with meaningfull insights
Paper structure, and analysis. How to tackle a research prompt, and write an adequate paper.

How to write a research paper, how to analyze different forms of sources (such as film or video) and utilize them in essays, how to think about the virtual spaces we use (from chatrooms to virtual reality spaces) and their relationship to reality.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths within this course would the amount of student engagement, there were many students participating during class discussions. Each reading was always something different than last time, so it was nice to constantly gain some knowledge about virtual reality. Also, there were meetings held for each person individually with the teacher that helped students within the class. Something that could be improved would be the inclusion of more visual examples of VR. There were a couple of videos throughout the semester. I feel like this would have been nice to include once in a while.

Strengths: Especially given the online format, Prof Doyle was so sweet, kind, and understanding. She had expectations for us but always ensured that they were within reach. I also liked the topics that were covered - virtual reality and the concept of virtuality are fascinating, pertinent topics.
Weaknesses: The progression of writing was inconsistent. I feel that I could have had been taught a better foundation of how to craft arguments earlier on. Instead of having only a few bigger essays, more small-scale assignments that focus more narrowly on crafting different aspects of an argument would've been more helpful.
The course is very accessible. Everything that you need to know for the class is introduced in class, and I feel like this makes it easier to improve your writing during the semester.

I thought that this was a very engaging English seminar that introduced me to the expectations of college-level papers. Each paper assignment was clear and provided freedom for the student to fully express their own thoughts and synthesize the information they learned from the sources. One thing that I would improve is that before diving into the first paper, it would be better to get a little more class time to learn about the standards of writing.

I think that towards the end the readings were somewhat unecessary as when we read them we went over them in class once and then never saw them again. I enjoyed it more when we workshopped our papers in class rather than discussing long readings
I found it a very helpful course. The readings were adequately varied and provide much useful information.

Strength:
The material was very interesting and the pacing of essays and projects was good. Very good for learning some basic skills related to doing research in the first year.

Weakness:
I did feel like it was more focused on teaching about the essay writing than about the content that relates to the title of the course (Virtual Humans), but I guess that's normal for a first year writing course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: During this course, practices like having everyone's camera and mic on was really nice. It brought more of that feeling of being in an in-person class because of all the interactions that were had. Along with this, the changing of research groups for each paper was a good way to make friends in the class, which did prove to be difficult during this time of covid.

The essay writing could be a little more structured, at least at first. Providing a more rigid structure to our essays earlier on could help us understand the fundamental elements necessary to our argument for later essays, which would have more freedom in terms of structure.
The online discussion format was also not engaging. The zoom was very quiet and not many people were willing to express their opinions.
This course was had effective utilization of breakout rooms and opportunities to meet with our course's writing tutor. I like how we did virtual field trips and wrote discussion posts about it.
I believe that the class was carried out in the best way possible given the limitations of Zoom.
I thought the course went well and group discussion warranted a response from all students
I do not see much improvement being needed. The course was adequately adjusted with the online communications.

The seminars were very engaging, and there was a lot of time for discussion, which made students feel like they could get a lot out of the interaction even if it's a virtual environment.
A bit more engagement with the online discussion board might make the experience even better.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, especially if you want a smooth transition from high school to college writing. It is a class that goes step by step in the college writing process and helps set up well for the rest of college writing. Also, the readings are very interesting and the classes are pretty small, so you'll be learning new things about a topic and be able to interact with most people in the class.

I would recommend this course to anyone who feels they need to develop a better foundation in "Yale writing." Otherwise, if you are looking for engaging discussions on complicated topics, I'd recommend looking elsewhere.

I would recommend this course. You can learn a lot from your professor, peers, writing tutor, and the readings. The workload is clearly laid out and very manageable if you allocate a bit of time regularly to keep up with the reading and writing. I enjoyed the topic of our course on virtual humans and the freedom of our 3rd and 4th papers.
Yes -- English 114 is a great way to get introduced to college writing. I would definitely recommend this course to first years or anyone who has not taken a writing/English class at Yale before.
Yes, especially during a pandemic and the world becoming increasingly virtual it is a very interesting topic to talk about and Prof. Doyle was amazing
Yes, it puts you in a great position to tackle college papers and college writing.
I would recommend it to first year students who want a writing credit early or who would like to learn some basics in writing essays/ research papers before taking harder classes later on.
